title: FX: U.S. And Canadian Data Put Central Banks On High(er) Alert
text:
Retail Sales out of the U.S. and CPI out of Canada were released on Wednesday and both were big misses.

Question: Who do most economists say is driving the US economy?

Answer: The U.S. Consumer

“Don’t bet against the U.S. consumer” is another adage that is often thrown around.

U.S. Retail Sales for September were released and the results were not pretty for the U.S. Economy. The (MoM) was -0.3% vs 0.3% expected, with an upward revision from 0.4% to 0.6%. Although the revision to the August number was higher, it still nets a big miss. This is the first time Retail Sales has fallen in seven months. (excluding autos) was just as bad, with a (MoM) reading for September of -0.1% vs 0.2% expected. This may be one of the first signs that the U.S. consumer is concerned about the poor manufacturing data and modest jobs data. With the US-China trade deal still ongoing, consumers may be concerned about a pinch in their pocketbooks when and if tariffs are introduced. The Retail Sales data just adds another piece of negative data that the FOMC must consider at their next meeting. The market is currently pricing in an 88% of 25bps on October 30.

CPI for September from Canada was also published. was -0.4% vs -0.2% expected. Although (excluding food and energy) for September (MoM) was in line with expectations at 0%, it was still a net negative for the Canadian economy, as inflation data last month was bad as well. Although were good for Canada in September, the BOC must deal with weaker (last reading was from August) and continued lower inflation.

was violently unchanged after the data from both countries was released at the same time. As we discussed with the employment data, price currently is trading in the longer-term range. On the daily chart, price is still coiling in the apex of the longer-term triangle. A break above 1.3400 or below 1.3150 should provide a longer-term direction, however 1.3150 is well supported. Bulls will look to get long near this level while watching for a move toward the top of the triangle.
